bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Acting Ambassador to Cuba, November 19, 1952

div1.p: Hench describes the upcoming Camp Lazear dedication and encourages the ambassador to attend, in support of Cuban-American friendship. He sends him background information explaining the delicacy of the situation and refers to the Finlay-Reed controversy.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Acting Ambassador to Cuba, November 19, 1952
div1.opener:
November 19, 1952
His Excellency
The Acting Ambassador to Cuba
American Embassy
Havana, Cuba
Your Excellency:
div1.p:
Perhaps you have already been informed that on December 3 certain Cuban
officials will dedicate at the Finca San Jose, Quemados de Marianao, the
old “Camp Lazear” where, in 1900-1901, Major Walter Reed, physician of the
U. S. Army and his associates proved the correctness of the mosquito theory
of the Cuban physician, Dr. Carlos Finlay. I sincerely hope that you and
your colleagues have been invited to attend and participate in this ceremony
which, though it may be modest, is of considerable significance as far as
Cuban-American friendship, especially Cuban-American medical friendship,
is concerned. When you receive the invitation, I hope most sincerely that
you can accept and attend.

You are probably aware of the unfortunate debate which has continued for
fifty years in Cuba, a debate concerning the supposed American neglect of
Doctor Finlay in favor of Major Reed and his colleagues. There are many
sincere Cuban physicians and officials who greatly regret this debate and
who are joining together hoping that the Cuban memorialization of Camp
Lazear will cause the unfortunate contention to be dropped. You are probably
aware that until now not a single monument or honor to Reed exists in Cuba
nor does his name even appear on tablets honoring Doctor Finlay and including
at least some of Reed's subordinates. Therefore it is of considerable sig-
nificance that the Cuban Government is officially honoring Camp Lazear and
the Americans who so magnificently proved the correctness of Doctor Finlay's
conception. They are making a gracious gesture and many in our country
appreciate it greatly.

So that you may know of some of the delicate maneuvering that has preceded
the ceremony of December 3, may I send you in confidence herewith three
letters and a reprint. If you do not have time to read the reprint, may I
earnestly request that your secretary make for you a synopsis of the letters.

General Paul Streit, Commanding General of Walter Reed Hospital, has been
appointed by the Surgeon General of the U. S. Army to attend the ceremony
and he will attend. I will officially represent the Mayo Foundation. The
Mayo Foundation has asked me to honor Doctor Finlay by placing a wreath
beneath the medallion when it is unveiled on December 3. It may well be
that General Streit will be authorized to lay a wreath or wreaths in honor

The Acting Ambassador to Cuba

of Doctor Finlay and/or Major Reed. Whether or not you and your colleagues
would care to do likewise I leave to you to consider and decide. If there
might be a plethora of wreaths placed during the ceremonies, it might be
well for General Streit or me to lay one on the grave of Doctor Finlay in
a quiet little ceremony, attended we hope by your representative and a
representative of the Cuban Government.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
